wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant-General Sir Louis Ridley Vaughan  (7 August 1875 – 7 December 1942), was a British Indian Army staff officer and First World War general. During the First World War, he served on the Western Front, and was chief of staff to General Sir Julian Byng, commander of the Third Army from May 1917 until the end of the war. After the war, he served in the Third Anglo-Afghan War of 1919, and then held several army positions in India until his retirement in 1928. He died in 1942 at the age of 67.

They were still preoccupied with the attack at Bourlon Wood on the left, and did not believe – wrongly – that the Germans had sufficient reserves left after Third Ypres to mount a major attack.Hammond 2008, pp. 328–29, 439 At 7pm on 28 November his chief of staff, Brigadier-General Jock Burnett-Stuart, telephoned Julian Byng's chief of staff, Major-General Louis Vaughan, to request reinforcements and was told that the Guards Division could soon be sent. However, when the counterattack came, the Guards Division had already been committed to III Corps.Hammond 2008, pp. 332, 354
